text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

Solid by António Bagorro
This strong landscape photograph makes an impact with the unusual-shaped stone dominating the scene. The deep blacks contrast with the highlights on the stone, making it more striking still. The sharpness of this contrasts well against the soft blur of the sea, giving a good balance to the image of hard and soft, and light and shadow.

Mountain Ibex - Chamonix, French Alps by Örvar Atli Þorgeirsson
The photographer was lucky to capture these ibex just at the perfect moment. Not only are the clearly energetic ibex sharply in focus, but the composition is good too. The ibex on the right is perfectly positioned within the ‘V’ shape of the mountain range behind, and the lighter colours of the distance mountains make it even more prominent.

Breakfast with chocolate & cranberry madeleine by Anna Verdina
It is clear to see that a lot of time, effort, and consideration has gone into the set-up and composition of this photograph. We get the impression that the positioning of the table arrangement – down to every last berry – has been meticulously thought out. This photograph aims to create an inviting scene that lures you in; that makes you want to reach right into the picture and pick up a madeleine. This is what good food photography is all about.

Breath of Autumn by ’Danired’
With the sun shining through and lighting the cobwebs on the heather, we can’t help but think of a crisp autumnal morning. We love the bokeh and the curve of the cobwebs which lies in line with the curve of light in the background.

Intactness by Jessica Ellen
Wow. This is an image with real impact, and as a portrait it’s very unusual. We think it works because the lighting is just spot-on; the girl is perfectly lit within the smoke from the fire, and any background distractions are almost non-existant due to the heavy vignetting which renders the background very dark.

或る実る光 by Tomoyuki Shinohara
This image is slightly overexposed, but we believe that photography rules are made to be broken and in this case, the fact that it is overexposed adds to the dream-like quality of the picture. The subtle sun-flare and out-of-focus grasses in the foreground create a wonderfully soft feel to this image, while the figure of the girl in the distance surrounded by the long grass provides an air of mystery. All-in-all, this is an enchanting photograph.

Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine! Our special thanks this week to Gunnlaugur Örn Valsson, HyunJung Jung, Kazuhito Takenaka and Simon Goyne.

Manhattanhenge on May 31, 2012 by Steven Kelley
With all that New York City has seen recently after she has been battered and bruised by Hurricane Sandy, we felt it was apt to make this image our Photo of the Day.

Lagarfljót by Brian Rueb
The abandoned house neatly sits at the point of the image where a sea of colours converge; the pastel colours of the sky, the milky white of the water, the grey of the stone, and the green of the grass. This, together with its off-centred position, allows your eye to fall straight to the house as the main subject of the image, whilst instantly getting the most of the vibrant colours. It’s a colour-feast for the eyes.

Dawn at Nash Point by Jeff Morgan
The long-exposure here has created the impression of a perfectly calm sea. Getting up early to capture the dawn light was certainly worthwhile as the soft pastel colours of the sunrise provide a nice contrast to the cold blue tones of the foreground. We also like the subtle vignette, which helps to draw your eye to the lighter part of the sea just off centre of the image.

Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

Light and Shade by Carmen Morosan
There’s more to this apparently simple image than meets the eye. With the bull almost lost in shadow, and the matador bathed in sunlight, the two adversaries are linked by the strong diagonal that cuts right across the frame.

How Hill by Geoff Tibbenham
A lovely, tranquil image to get the week off to a relaxing start! We especially like the subtle colours of the clouds in the sky, and the sense that the water’s edge is receding into the distant haze.

Toes by Noelle Buske
This is a great example of a tight crop taken to extremes. The soft light, the muted colours and the beautiful foreground bokeh all combine to create an image that is greater than the sum of its parts. Another wish-you-were-there gem.

In the Midst of it All by Carolyn Cochrane
Here’s a beautifully backlit image to brighten up your weekend. It’s hard to put your finger on what makes this shot so special - the composition doesn’t obey any of the ‘rules’, the background is deliberately over-exposed, and the subject is pretty everyday - but somehow it just works.

Providence by Rob Macklin
How about this to welcome in the weekend? Rob’s image has a real wish-you-were-there quality, thanks to the immediacy of the flowers in the foreground, the warm light on the distant peaks, and the leading lines of the tree-clad slopes in between.

To fade in and nothing else by Sophia Alexis
Location portraits taken from low viewpoint, and with the foreground blurred out, seem to be all the rage at the moment, and Sophia’s image is a brilliantly executed example. With shots like this the danger is the subject getting lost in the foreground, or background, or both, but here the model’s wistful gaze is perfectly captured in the soft, early-morning light.

Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

Mundo azul by Luis Gonzalez
This stunning macro shot by Luis Gonzalez is perfectly composed and beautifully lit, but as the title suggests, it’s the muted blue colour palette of the background that really makes it.

Corfe Castle by Mike Byford
Here’s something to brighten up your Monday! Corfe Castle in Dorset, UK, is a popular subject, but it’s not often you see it captured in an image as accomplished and atmospheric as this. We especially like contrast between the cool blues on the left and the warmer colours on the right.

Rays by Marcin Sobas
From bright and breezy to mean and moody. A quick glance at Marcin’s on-line portfolio (see below) shows that he is a master of mist and side-lighting, and in this stunning shot they’ve been combined to great effect.

Miri by Jack Batchelor
We’re often advised to avoid symmetry when photographing people, but in this breezy image by portrait specialist Jack Batchelor, positioning the model at the centre of the frame has resulted in a really striking composition. We also like the blurred flowers, the subdued colours and the deliberate vignetting in the corners, which combine to give the finished image a satisfyingly low-fi feel.

Cape Kiwanda by Bill Ratcliffe
Capturing the power and energy of the sea in a still image is a real challenge, so we’re grateful to Bill Ratcliffe for showing us how it’s done…! The key to a shot like this is the timing of the exposure, and ensuring that the shutter is open as the waves are receding rather than breaking, as this creates a sense of movement as the spent waves suck back over the rocks.

Black Eyed Susan by Jacob Edmiston
Jacob’s ultra-vibrant image of a black-eyed Susan, which has to be viewed large to be fully appreciated, provides a masterclass in the use of complementary colours. The vivid yellow really stands out against the cobalt-blue of the blurred background, and this blue is echoed in the tightly-packed carpels at the centre of the flower.

Goodbye Cruel World… by Salah Baazizi
“This rock dove (or pigeon) landed next to me on the bridge at Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve in California. As they live under the bridge, instead of taking to the sky like most birds, it dived down.”

Balconies by Mark Coe
”This is a shot of the balconies of a new development of apartments along the seafront in Chalkwell Southend-On-Sea, England. They really stand out as the building is flanked by other dull-looking apartment blocks, so they have become something of a local landmark.”

Fascinating Beauty by Andrea Rapisarda
”I took this shot at the Rome Photoshow in March 2012. This beautiful model was posing on Sony’s stand at the event.”

Booted Warbler by Niranj Vaidyanathan
”To photograph this warbler, I lay on the ground at an angle that favoured good light and a background that would give me a good bokeh, and moved in closer along on the ground to avoid alert the bird.”

Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page.
Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full. Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine! Our special thanks this week to Fredy Mihaila, Yuga Kurita and Daniel Enderle.

Elisabetta by Paolo Mezzera
”Elisabetta is 13-years-old and from Italy. This image is part of a series of of shots published on my website. Usually I dislike black and white conversions, but in this case I really love how it works.”

The Sagrada Família by Daniel Borg
”The architecture and attention to detail in the building of The Sagrada Família is simply beautiful and I wanted to convey that beauty in one image. To capture this I used an Ultra Wide Angle lens.”

Hello Morning! by Celeste Mookherjee
”I love photographing morning glories because they can appear lit from within. When one is out of macro reach, I often switch to a zoom lens, which I did for this photograph.”

Midnight Reflections by Matthew Bleakley
“A pallid bat skims across a pond in southern Arizona. The yellow on the wings is pollen picked up by the bat. Off-camera flashes were fired using a custom-built infra-red trigger.”

Gelato by Kristina Kurtze
”This photo is of gelato with a candied orange slice. I used a Nikon SB800 with an umbrella to the right of the gelato and a reflector behind it and slightly to the left, angled towards the flash.”

Black Grouse by David Newby
“This image of a male black grouse was taken on a private estate in the Yorkshire Dales, UK, in March 2012. After a very early start on a misty morning, the sun came out, and so did the grouse.”

The Big Eye by Vincent Bourrut
“This is the spiral staircase at Heal’s department store in London. I knew the picture I wanted to take – my aim was to bring out the detail in the wood.”

Sapa, Vietnam by Diego Arroyo
“I took this shot of a Hmong woman in a rice field in the region of Sapa, in north Vietnam.”

By adegsm
This unusual shot anthropomorphises the insects: positioned as they are, you can’t help but see them as two lovers, gazing into each other’s beady eyes, sitting in a romantic location atop a flower.

Schafsteize by Walter Hupfer
“When I was out walking my dogs, we were observed suspiciously by a blue-headed wagtail, which was probably guarding its nest. When it perched on a stalk of wheat, I took this photo.”

The Sky’s The Limit by Yosuke Kobayashi
“These buildings stand at the southern end of Manhattan. The tallest you can see here is One World Trade Center, which is under construction.”

Ghostly Cub by Jordi Fernandez
“I took this in Lebala camp, Botswana. We were photographing lionesses when this cub approached us from behind. I lay as low as possible on the car for a low angle while trying to get the sun disk out of the frame.”

Surge by Alex De Sonnaville
“This was taken at Natural Bridges State Park in Santa Cruz, California. I originally set out to take long exposures, but decided to go with a quicker shutter speed in order to take advantage of the great foreground created by the waves.”

Burning Peak by Shantikara T. Valuska
“The Matterhorn reflected in a small mountain lake high up in the Alps. I hiked up here very early in the morning to catch the magical moment when the first rays of the sun touch the top of the mountain.”

Freedom by Guillermina Sogo
“This was taken during the first day of ‘Rapas das Bestas’ in Sabucedo, Spain. About 200 wild horses are caught, then marked with microchips before being set free. Here the heat from the horses produced a steam visible in the shot.”

Issue 99 of Photography Week is on sale now!
This week’s we take the best quotes from some of the biggest names in photography and explore what you can take from them to improve your own photography – from Capa to Cartier-Bresson, this is a masterclass you won’t want to miss.

Horse Ballet by Lisa Mardell
“A Lusitano stallion showing off for the camera at the Coudelaria Henrique Abecasis stud farm in Portugal. Lusitanos love to perform and their big personalities and beautiful manes make them a compelling subject to photograph.”

Cantabria Infinita… by Jose Miquel Romano
“This place is known as Los Urros, near Liencres in Cantabria, Spain. The photograph was taken late one day. The moon illuminated the scene from the left, while the setting sun provided the warm lighting from the right.”

Priceless Moments by Ash Kapoor
“I took this on a walk in Varanasi on the banks of the Ganga in India. I saw this old lady sitting outside her house, and felt a connection with her. I chatted with her, then asked if I could take her picture.”

A New Beginning by Ash Kapoor
“I took this shot on an early morning walk on the Ghats of Varanasi, India, where I saw this pandit (priest) relaxing. The sun was just rising, and I found it interesting to get this low angle shot showing the horizon.”

Súla / Northern Gannet / Morus Bassanus by Ágúst Þór Bjarnason
“The Northern Gannet is the largest member of the Gannet family. I was at sea south-west of the Faroe Islands when I took this photo, which is one of many that evening in perfect dawn and seascape environment.”

Nate Florence at Pipeline by John Hook
This was a huge swell on the north shore of Oahu island, Hawaii. I swam out with my camera and stayed in position for a few hours shooting. As the sun set it made a beautiful backlight from the wave.“

Flapping Wings by Nando Pizzini
“I took this shot of an Atlantic puffin flapping its wings one evening on the Runde Cliffs, an island that lies off the western coast of Norway.”

Gold Bar Rim - Moab Canyon below - Moab, UT by Eddie Tkowski
“I’ve known about this spot for some time, having mountain biked here for years. I tell people to go to the edge for the view, but they have no idea they’re on an overhang like this!”

Latest issue of Photography Week out now!
This week we have a fantastic creative photo project for you to try that involves a feather, some water droplets and a close-up lens. Oh, and if you haven’t got a dedicated macro lens, we show you how to get up close and personal on a budget.

Erm by Marc Jardot
“I wanted to make a high contrast image. As the weather was favorable, we headed out to shoot, and I chose this place as the background would create a great bokeh and would be good for a high contrast image.”

Up, up and away by Vichaya Chatikavanij
“I took this during a trip to West Java, Indonesia. To get this composition of children playing in the water, I also had to wade out to the middle of the stream. The blur is from the morning fog and backlighting.”

The latest issue of Photography Week is out now! Don’t forget you can get this issue – and the next five issues – completely FREE with our obligation-free trial at http://goo.gl/DWC7ND.
Here’s what you’ve got to look forward to this week:

Gecko by Leon Dafonte Fernandez
“I took this where I live in Palm Cove, Queensland, Australia. I saw the gecko sitting on a the leaf of a tree on the beach, illuminated by the light of the sunset, and shot this handheld.”

Heybrook Bay by Jed Langdon
“This was taken in a small cove at Heybrook Bay, Plymouth. The sea was particularly choppy on this morning, so I used a long exposure to create a misty look around these rocks, with the Mewstone in the background.”

Lupine Field by Ryan Engstrom
This is a shot of Folsom lake in California. The lupine bloom here for a couple weeks a year in late April to mid May. During sunset the fading light can cast a soft warm glow that really lights up the flowers.“

Hepatica by Andreas Hagman
“It’s a tradition for me to capture the first flowers to pop up every spring. I like the Hepatica for their glowing colour when everything else is still dead and grey. This was taken in the countryside of southern Sweden.”

Crystal ball and coloured lights by Vivien Juhasz-Dora
“This is a photograph of a crystal ball lying on the railing of a bridge in Frankfurt, Germany. I focused on the skyline inside the ball with colourful lights creating a bokeh background.”

By Pysixx
This image uses a narrow aperture, lightly textured background, and soft colour palette to create an unusual fine-art flower photograph.

Rays by Marcin Sobas
“This photo was taken in August 2009, in the Beskidy Mountains in Poland. It was the start of a hot day, and a low fog hung in the valley. As the sun rose it lit the valley, creating an amazing scene.” – Marcin

Drom by Johannes Heuckeroth
“This image shows the Tempodrom building in Berlin, Germany. To get the most out of its architecture, I took five portrait-format wide-angle photos and stitched them together.” – Johannes

Inupiat Elder by Clark Mishler
Inupiat elder and natural sciences advisor Kenny Toovak, with fur ruff, on the coast of the Arctic Ocean near Barrow, Alaska.

Young Male Merlin by Claire Marshall
“I took this image on a bird-of-prey workshop at Sutton Bank in Yorkshire, UK. The light and location were spot on, and this little bird posed happily for photographers and assembled onlookers!” – Claire

Lea Jones with ‘Cricket’, a four-year-old Chihuahua-Miniature Pinscher cross, and Stacey Scott with 'Bono’, a four-year-old Chihuahua-Shih Tzu cross.
This shot was taken by Clark Mishler, whom we interviewed in issue 24 of Photography Week iPad magazine.
